item.title: Sony Confirms Bungie‚Äôs Marathon Will Launch by March 2026
item.content:encoded:
Sony has once again reconfirmed that Bungie‚Äôs extraction-based shooter, Marathon, will launch by March 2026.

The confirmation came during the company‚Äôs quarterly earnings call, where Sony‚Äôs CFO, Lin Tao, said that Bungie‚Äôs Marathon was still in active development and that the company was ‚Äúfully dedicated‚Äù to launching the game in the current fiscal year. Sony‚Äôs fiscal year ends March 2026, suggesting that Marathon will likely launch sometime in February to March, if we were to guess.

Marathon has had an uphill battle since it was first announced earlier this year, with the game struggling to captivate players and the studio facing a slew of plagiarism allegations, of which Bungie later admitted. The issues facing the gam led to a delay of an undisclosed length.

But is Marathon Good Now?

However, as recently as the game‚Äôs latest playtests at the end of October, which were apparently under NDA, Bungie has apparently been able to turn things around with its game.

According to those who played the latest version of the game, it‚Äôs apparently in a much better state now, with players looking forward to its release in the coming months.

The game was said to be a ‚Äòsignificant improvement‚Äô since the playtests in the summer, yet the game still had some minor issueswhich were said to be easily fixed.

Whether Marathon will be a success on launch remains to be seen, but with GTA 6 now slipping into November 2026 and the start of the year seemingly being relatively quiet now, it could launch to some interest.

ARC Raiders is clearly the game‚Äôs most immediate competition, but if Marathon launches in March 2026, ARC Raiders‚Äô playerbase and hype will likely have whittled down considerably.

item.title: Battlefield 6 1.1.1.5 Update Full Patch Notes‚ÄîWeapon Accuracy Tweaks & Vehicle Countermeasures
item.content:encoded:
A fresh update has been deployed for Battlefield 6, introducing a variety of quality-of-life tweaks that impact various aspects of the game, and we‚Äôve got the patch notes.

The 1.1.1.5 update for Battlefield 6 was made available on November 11 at 9 AM UTC, with tweaks to weapon accuracy, refinements to vehicle countermeasure reliability, improvements to Battle Royale match flow, and improved gameplay stability.

The biggest updates included fixing an exploit that allowed players to access unintended areas when standing on a Recon Drone, fixing an issue where enemy countermeasures did not effectively counter Lock-Guided Missiles, and vehicle spawning issues in Breakthrough and Conquest.

In REDSEC Battle Royale, multiple issues impacting match flow, squad revives, and end-of-round transitions were fixed, as well as a specific progression issue.

Battlefield 6 1.1.1.4 Update Full Patch Notes

The complete patch notes for Battlefield 6‚Äôs 1.1.1.4 update are available below, as shared by the official Battlefield Comms page on X (formerly Twitter).

Major Updates for 1.1.1.5:

  • Fixed an exploit allowing players to ascend and access unintended areas when standing on a XFGM-6D Recon Drone by hitting it with the Sledgehammer.
  • Fixed an issue where Lock-Guided Missiles did not get countered as expected when met with enemy countermeasures such as flares.
  • Fixed an issue where vehicles did not spawn correctly in Breakthrough and Conquest.
  • Fixed multiple Battle Royale issues affecting match flow, squad revives, and End of Round transitions.
  • Addressed progression, audio, and UI issues, improving overall clarity, reliability, and immersion.

CHANGELOG

PLAYER:

  • Fixed an issue where dispersion would be higher than intended when going from sprint to firing in ADS.
  • Fixed an issue where dispersion would incorrectly scale with movement speed and always assume the player is moving at maximum movement speed for the stance.
  • Tuned landing animation to reduce excessive camera and weapon movement when aiming down sights, improving visual stability during and after landing. This update also resolves instances where the ADS aim could be displaced when sliding.

VEHICLES:

  • Fixed an issue where Lock-Guided Missiles did not get countered as expected when met with enemy countermeasures such as flares.

GADGETS:

  • Fixed an exploit allowing players to ascend and access unintended areas when standing on the XFGM-6D Recon Drone by hitting it with the Sledgehammer.

MAPS & MODES:

  • Fixed an issue where vehicles did not spawn correctly in Breakthrough and Conquest.
  • Fixed an issue where matches sometimes would start with all sectors and objectives active at the same time.
  • Fixed an issue in Strikepoint on Siege of Cairo where destruction did not reset at halftime.

UI & HUD:

  • Fixed an issue in Vehicle Customisation locked Anti-Air Vehicle presets did not display their unlock criteria as intended.

PROGRESSION:

  • Fixed an issue where the shotgun weapon challenge ‚ÄúKill 5 Enemies With a Shotgun Without Reloading‚Äù did not complete properly.
  • Fixed an issue where progress for the ‚ÄúEngineer Specialist 3‚Äù Assignment did not save correctly.

PORTAL:

  • Fixed an issue where ‚ÄúSpawnLoot‚Äù would not spawn Ammo or Armor.
  • Fixed an issue where players with community creations privileges set to Block could still access user-generated Community Experiences when the party leader hosted a match.

AUDIO:

  • Fixed an issue where activating the BF PRO Radio Channel through the Commorose did not play any sound.

REDSEC

PLAYER:

  • Fixed an issue where Battle Royale (Quads) matches did not end after the last team was eliminated.
  • Fixed an issue where being killed immediately after a mobile respawn completed could result in the squad being eliminated instead of reviving remaining teammates.
  • Fixed an issue where players could become stuck in a top-down view of the map after redeploying.
  • Fixed an issue where players retained their Second Chance after redeploying and did not transition to the End of Round screen after their next elimination.

UI & HUD:

  • Fixed an issue where all squad members displayed the same highlighted stat on the Squad Placement screen.

PROGRESSION:

  • Fixed an issue where the ‚ÄúBattle Royal Master Challenge 4‚Äù did not track progress correctly.

item.title: Fortnite to Add Gambling in a Future Update, Leak Reveals
item.content:encoded:
Fortnite is set to make a controversial addition in a future update, it‚Äôs claimed, with gambling mechanics set to be directly added to the title.

Huge updates are on the cards for Fortnite with Chapter 7 due to kick off later this month, and the annual switch in chapters usually results in the biggest gameplay changes of the year.

While we‚Äôve already seen leaks suggesting huge collabs with the likes of SpongeBob Squarepants and Harry Potter are on the cards, the apparent addition of gambling will ruffle some feathers.

Fortnite Will Add Gambling Mechanics

According to reliable leaker ShiinaBR, gambling mechanics are ‚Äúcoming soon‚Äù in Fortnite and will be available to games created using the Unreal Editor in Fortnite.

It‚Äôs not entirely clear whether official Fortnite experiences will support gambling, or whether content link loot boxes will be added to the Item Shop, but it appears that it will be available in community-created experiences.

According to leaks, random items will be purchasable with V-Bucks, but creators will be required to disclose gambling odds‚Äîsomething commonplace in gaming to align with international laws. Additionally, due to laws in some nations, experiences with gambling involved will be blocked in some nations.

While gambling aspects are already available in some user-created experiences within Fortnite, including pet eggs with a rare chance to hatch specific creatures in games like Pet Heroes Adventure, the major difference is that these are paid for with in-game soft currency that is not purchasable.

With this update, V-Bucks will be directly available to spend on items that provide random rewards, though it‚Äôs unclear at this stage what exactly that will entail, and it will likely depend on the experience being played.

item.title: Where Winds Meet Hits 10m Pre-Registrations
item.content:encoded:
Where Winds Meet has hit a staggering tally of pre-registrations in the days before the big global launch, with the final community goal met and additional rewards set to be distributed.

The free-to-play RPG from Everstone Studios and NetEase Game is set for release on Friday, November 14, and an impressive tally of pre-registrations has already resulted in a heap of rewards for players.

However, that tally has now been extended further to surpass the final community goal, resulting in even more rewards for players and showcasing the high anticipation for the game.

Where Winds Meet His 10m Pre-Registrations

On November 10, four days before the global launch, Where Winds Meet surpassed the 10 million pre-registration mark, unlocking the final community reward.

Anticipation for the title is high, with pre-load for the title on Steam available 48 hours before release, with PlayStation 5 players who purchased the pre-order bundle able to do the same.

Where Winds Meet has a staggering amount of content to dive into, with over 100 hours of single-player content, PvP experiences, a heap of side quests, and tons of exploration.

The title was initially released in China in December 2024 and is now poised for a global release, bringing the Wuxia adventure to players around the world.

item.title: Bethesda‚Äôs Latest Update is Awful News for Fallout Fans
item.content:encoded:
In a recent interview, Bethesda Game Studios‚Äô Todd Howard revealed that The Elder Scrolls 6 is still ‚Äòa long way off‚Äô, despite being revealed almost a decade ago. It‚Äôs dire news for fans of The Elder Scrolls, who haven‚Äôt received a new ‚Äònumbered release‚Äô since 2011‚Äôs Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.

However, in a twist that might displease post-apocalyptic fans, the knock-on impact of this news is that Fallout 5 will be even further away than anticipated. The studio‚Äôs production line will see The Elder Scrolls 6 on the market before Fallout 5 even enters meaningful development, which is a big issue for fans of the decades-old series.

Fallout 5 Could Be Ten Years Away

In a recent interview with GQ around the tenth anniversary of Fallout 4, celebrated by the release of the Anniversary Edition, Todd Howard touched on the increasingly long development window of The Elder Scrolls 6. He suggested that the open-world RPG is a long way off and that fans should be ‚Äòpatient‚Äô.

This presents a tricky issue for Fallout fans.

While Fallout 76 is here and still receiving massive updates, a numbered Fallout release (by that I mean Fallout 5) is likely several years away from being released, if it ever surfaces at all.

We know that the team is working on ‚Äòmore Fallout‚Äô, but that doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean Fallout 5. It most likely means Fallout 3 Remastered or a New Vegas project.

It has been known for several years that Bethesda Game Studios‚Äô running order would take them from Starfield to The Elder Scrolls 6 to Fallout 5. Given that we don‚Äôt have a release year for The Elder Scrolls 6, it could be a while before it hits the market. That means that for as long as it takes to get out the door, Fallout 5 will take even longer to appear.

Presently, we know nothing about Fallout 5. There‚Äôs not a shred of information to share aside from knowing that Bethesda Game Studios has a core concept for the game.

Bad news, apocalypse fans ‚Äì you‚Äôve got a while longer to wait.

item.title: Embark Reveals ARC Raiders Player Count, and 64% of Them Are On Steam
item.content:encoded:
ARC Raiders continues to impress, and the player count is not only holding firm as the game‚Äôs lifecycle pushes on ‚Äì it‚Äôs growing. The game has gone from strength to strength, and with a roadmap of content sitting on the horizon alongside that positive community sentiment, the game shows no signs of slowing down.

Recently, Embark Studios revealed that the game hit a concurrent user count of 700,000 players over the weekend across all platforms. From the data we‚Äôve collected, we know that a whopping 64% majority of those players were present on Steam.

The extraction shooter genre (however dumb the name may be) has always been front and centre on PC. From Escape from Tarkov to Marauders, and from Gray Zone Warfare to Arena Breakout: Infinite, the PC platform loves an extraction title.

The latest addition to the lineup is ARC Raiders, released on October 30 and introducing an all-new concept to the genre, a ‚Äòpost-apocalyptic‚Äô setting backed by an AI-powered robotic threat.

ARC Raiders is on PlayStation, Xbox, and PC, but the latest figures revealed by Embark Studios paint a particular picture.

More than 64% of players are on Steam, showing that adoption is perhaps lacking somewhat on PlayStation and Xbox. With a market share of just 36%, console players are showing a lack of investment in the exhilarating extraction shooter.

It‚Äôs a fair statement, as the ‚Äòextraction shooter concept‚Äô is new to console-exclusive gamers. Until now, almost nothing with this operating model has appeared on console, save for failed titles like Call of Duty‚Äôs DMZ.

If you‚Äôre reading this and wondering if you should try ARC Raiders on console but are sceptical about the genre, let me point out that this is the highest-rated multiplayer shooter in almost a decade.

ARC Raiders continues to sit high on the charts. Let me know on the Insider Gaming Discord server if you intend to invest in the game.

item.title: Diablo 4‚Äôs Chinese Version Has Been Censored in a Weird Way
item.content:encoded:
Diablo 4 is all about high-octane combat, impressive visuals, and rivers of hot, red blood. It‚Äôs a game tied inexorably to the occult, the underworld, and the afterlife, known for grotesque monsters, visceral sequences, and intense battles that keep the blood and guts flowing.

That‚Äôs why it comes as a surprise to some to learn that Diablo 4‚Äôs ‚ÄòChinese version‚Äô, which was approved for release a few months ago, has been heavily censored, stripping all traces of blood from the game and replacing some boss characters‚Äô scarier skins with elements much more tame.

Diablo 4 Toned Down in China

Last year, Microsoft and NetEase penned a deal to distribute Blizzard‚Äôs games throughout China after leaving the region in 2023. In a drastic move that pushed Blizzard out of China, games like World of Warcraft, Overwatch, and Diablo were rendered unplayable there.

In July, several games were ‚Äòapproved‚Äô by China‚Äôs National Press and Publication Administration, and one of those games was Diablo 4, the critically acclaimed action RPG title released in 2023.

Now, reports have surfaced that Diablo 4‚Äôs Chinese version has been censored, with Blizzard having been forced (assumedly) to remove blood and too much gore from the game. In a post from WOWHead, screenshots were revealed showing a dust-like substance being present in a fight instead of red blood.

Additionally, elements like skulls and bones, common trappings of the underworld, have also been removed. Wandering Death, a boss character made of bones and passed souls, is now made of rocks.

No reason has been provided to explain the changes, but it‚Äôs assumed that it‚Äôs linked to rules against promoting superstition and the supernatural in China. It‚Äôs a cultural point, and the regulatory body wants to remove some of the more volatile depictions of death and decay.

Do you think China should slow down on the censorship, or is it not that deep? Let me know what you‚Äôre thinking on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

What is NYT Connections?

It would be remiss of me not to give a little foundational backstory before leaping into today‚Äôs NYT Connections clues and hints.

In June 2023, NYT Connections emerged as yet another game in the ever-growing New York Times lineup. This title soared immediately, and it‚Äôs easy to see why. As a free-to-play, accessible New York Times game, NYT Connections is available to users worldwide and can be played on either desktop devices or via a mobile app.

Playing NYT Connections on your commute or while waiting for a coffee is a fantastic way to kill a few minutes.

But how do you play NYT Connections?

It‚Äôs relatively simple, and that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs the best New York Times game, in my opinion.

The NYT team will provide you with a grid of 16 words once a day. The only task left up to you is to sort those words into four groups of four by finding their commonalities. Every NYT Connections puzzle has just one solution, and some words might have a double meaning, so it can sometimes be tricky to figure out the answers.

It‚Äôs also important to stress that the words are color-coded: yellow, blue, green, and purple. That‚Äôs in order of difficulty from least to most difficult, too.

What‚Äôs critical here is that you get four guesses every day, and if you use those, your NYT Connections answers for today will be out of reach, as it‚Äôll be game over.
